elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp020" view="all">(a) A ball and stick representation of the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in the <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane, showing two neighboring layers; hydrogen atoms, sodium cations and water molecules of crystallization have been omitted for clarity. (b) A mixed polyhedral and ball and stick view of the layer structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, showing the locations of the sodium cations and the coordinated water molecules. Color scheme: lead, dark gray spheres (a) or polyhedra (b); sodium, yellow spheres; oxygen, red spheres; carbon, black spheres. (For interpretation of the references in colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) A ball and stick representation of the structure of 1 in the bc plane, showing two neighboring layers; hydrogen atoms, sodium cations and water molecules of crystallization have been omitted for clarity. (b) A mixed polyhedral and ball and stick view of the layer structure of 1, showing the locations of the sodium cations and the coordinated water molecules. Color scheme: lead, dark gray spheres (a) or polyhedra (b); sodium, yellow spheres; oxygen, red spheres; carbon, black spheres. (For interpretation of the references in colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp025" view="all">A polyhedral view of the linking of lead polyhedra in a simple layer of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in the <ce:italic>ac</ce:italic> plane. The lead sites have been color-coded for ease in identification: Pb(1) sites, orange; Pb(2) sites, yellow; Pb(3) sites, green; Pb(4) sites, blue; Pb(5) sites, gray. (For interpretation of the references in colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

The lead sites have been color-coded for ease in identification: Pb(1) sites, orange; Pb(2) sites, yellow; Pb(3) sites, green; Pb(4) sites, blue; Pb(5) sites, gray. <ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp030" view="all">Ball and stick representations of the coordination spheres of the lead atoms of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The proximal oxygen donors are shown as filled gray spheres with solid bonds while the distal oxygen atoms are illustrated as open circles with dashed bonds.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp005" view="all">The reaction of Pb(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with trisodium citrate at pH 4.8 yields the two-dimensional compound, {Na(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}[Pb<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·9.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. The structure exhibits five distinct Pb(II) sites and four unique citrate coordination environments.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0045">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The reaction of Pb(NO3)2 with trisodium citrate at pH 4.8 yields the two-dimensional compound, {Na(H2O)3}[Pb5(C6H5O7)3(C6H6O7)(H2O)3]⋅9.5H2O. The structure exhibits five distinct Pb(II) sites and four unique citrate coordination environments.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0045">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp010" view="all">► Metal–citrate chemistry is relevant to biological transport by CitMHS proteins. ► Synthesis at pH 8.5 provides a novel Pb(II)–citrate complex. ► The 2-D structure of the complex is unique with both coordinated and uncoordinated –OH groups. ► There are five distinct Pb environments and four citrate environments.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

► Metal-citrate chemistry is relevant to biological transport by CitMHS proteins. ► Synthesis at pH 8.5 provides a novel Pb(II)-citrate complex. ► The 2-D structure of the complex is unique with both coordinated and uncoordinated -OH groups. ► There are five distinct Pb environments and four citrate environments.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp015" view="all">The reaction of lead(II) nitrate with trisodium citrate Na<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>) in a 1:22.5 ratio at pH 4.8 provides crystals of {Na(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}[Pb<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)]·9.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is two-dimensional and exhibits five distinct Pb(II) sites and four different modes of citrate bonding. The five lead sites all display hemidirected coordination geometries, that is, irregular distribution of neighboring oxygen atoms resulting in obvious gaps in the coordination spheres. Consequently, the lead coordination geometries exhibit proximal bonding to a number of oxygen donors, as well as distal interactions with nearest neighbors. The coordination numbers vary from 8 to 10, with ‘5+3’, ‘5+4’, ‘6+4’ and ‘7+3’ coordination modes where the first number refers to the proximal ligands and the second to the distal set. The four crystallographically distinct citrate groups include three with deprotonated carboxylate groups (C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> and one with a single protonated carboxyl group (C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. The citrate ligands bridge 3, 5, 7 and 7 lead sites. Three of the citrate groups exhibit tridentate chelation coordination to a lead site through two carboxylate oxygen donors and the hydroxyl groups. One citrate group projects an uncoordinated –OH group and a pendant protonated carboxyl group into the interlamellar domain. This latter carboxyl group coordinates to a sodium cation, which exhibits five coordinate geometry defined by three aqua ligands and the carbonyl oxygen of the –CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H groups in the basal plane and a citrate –OH donor in the apical position.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The reaction of lead(II) nitrate with trisodium citrate Na3(C6H5O7) in a 1:22.5 ratio at pH 4.8 provides crystals of {Na(H2O)3}[Pb5(H2O)3(C6H5O7)3(C6H6O7)]⋅9.5H2O (1). The structure of 1 is two-dimensional and exhibits five distinct Pb(II) sites and four different modes of citrate bonding. The five lead sites all display hemidirected coordination geometries, that is, irregular distribution of neighboring oxygen atoms resulting in obvious gaps in the coordination spheres. Consequently, the lead coordination geometries exhibit proximal bonding to a number of oxygen donors, as well as distal interactions with nearest neighbors. The coordination numbers vary from 8 to 10, with ‘5+3', ‘5+4', ‘6+4' and ‘7+3' coordination modes where the first number refers to the proximal ligands and the second to the distal set. The four crystallographically distinct citrate groups include three with deprotonated carboxylate groups (C6H5O7)3- and one with a single protonated carboxyl group (C6H6O7)2. The citrate ligands bridge 3, 5, 7 and 7 lead sites. Three of the citrate groups exhibit tridentate chelation coordination to a lead site through two carboxylate oxygen donors and the hydroxyl groups. One citrate group projects an uncoordinated -OH group and a pendant protonated carboxyl group into the interlamellar domain. This latter carboxyl group coordinates to a sodium cation, which exhibits five coordinate geometry defined by three aqua ligands and the carbonyl oxygen of the -CO2H groups in the basal plane and a citrate -OH donor in the apical position.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Citric acid (2-hydroxypropane-1,2,3-tricarboxylic acid) is a ubiquitous source of carbon and energy for most living organisms . Many organisms have evolved primary or secondary membrane transporters that transport citrate coupled to Na+ or H+ or certain metal ions, particularly iron. Most bacterial citrate transporters carry free citrate and are actually inhibited by the addition of di- or tri-valent cations since they do not recognize the metal-citrate complex formed . Some unusual transporters, however, have evolved in strains of species such as Escherichia coli, Bacillus, Streptococcus, Neisseria, Kineococcus and Streptomyces that specifically recognize citrate in complexes with divalent metal ions . It is believed that these organisms take up complexed citrate because it is predominantly available as such in their habitat. Our particular interest has been in the investigation of energy independent symporters that transport metal-citrate complexes (CitMHS proteins). Very little is known about the CitMHS family . The functionally characterized systems for the metal-citrate transport carry metal-citrate complexes in symport with one H+ per metal-citrate. Lolkema et al. demonstrated that the metal-citrate integral membrane transporter CitM from Bacillus subtilis transported citrate in complex with Mg2+, Ni2+, Mn2+, Co2+ and Zn2+ but not in complex with Ca2+, Ba2+ and Sr2+. CitH, also from B. subtilis, transported citrate complexed to Ca2+, Ba2+ and Sr2+ but not Mg2+, Ni2+, Mn2+, Co2+ and Zn2+ . A CitH homolog has also been reported by Lolkema and co-workers from Enterococcus faecalis . Cvitkovitch et al. and Doyle et al. functionally characterized the only Fe(III)-citrate transporters reported to date from Streptococcus mutans  and Streptomyces coelicolor, respectively .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">These observations prove that metal–citrates can be transported across biological membranes allowing bacteria access to a pool of both select metal ions and energy in the form of citrate. Selectivity for certain metal–citrate complexes over uncomplexed ‘free’ citrate is achieved by a combination of complex stereochemistry, complex charge, complex nuclearity and transcription regulation. To truly understand the mechanistic workings of these proteins, the speciation of the metal–citrate complexes themselves must be understood. Citrate forms stable complexes with numerous divalent metal ions and is considered a pre-eminent, small molecular weight binder of metals in human blood plasma where it has a concentration of ∼0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM. The chemistry of citrate is complex with a variety of different binding modes reported. Binding of metal ions can occur at four sites: namely through the three carboxylate groups (p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>a<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.13, p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>a<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.76, p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>a<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.40) and the hydroxy group (p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>∼<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>11) , although the stability constants are sensitive to the medium . Furthermore, the deprotonation of the hydroxyl group of citric acid has proved a challenge for the determination of stability constants for metal citrates, and most studies treat citrate as the tribasic ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L . A more recent determination of the deprotonation at neutral pH values provides a value of 14.4 for the fourth p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>a , accounting for the hydroxyl deprotonation and making possible the assignment of the ligand as H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L in the affinity constant calculations. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>, the structural chemistry of the metal citrates is quite complex with bidentate complexes binding through dicarboxy donors reported for Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>
, Ca<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>
, and Ga<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>
, bidentate complexes involving the hydroxy group described for Ti(IV) , and Al(III) , for example, and tridentate complexes reported for Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Pb<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, and Cr<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, the latter showing different deprotonation states for the citrate ligands . The variety of dinuclear and oligomeric structures is consistent with the bridging propensity of the ligand donor groups . The majority of such complexes are mono-anionic with an important exception being the di-anionic Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>–citrate complex.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: These observations prove that metal-citrates can be transported across biological membranes allowing bacteria access to a pool of both select metal ions and energy in the form of citrate. Selectivity for certain metal-citrate complexes over uncomplexed ‘free' citrate is achieved by a combination of complex stereochemistry, complex charge, complex nuclearity and transcription regulation. To truly understand the mechanistic workings of these proteins, the speciation of the metal-citrate complexes themselves must be understood. Citrate forms stable complexes with numerous divalent metal ions and is considered a pre-eminent, small molecular weight binder of metals in human blood plasma where it has a concentration of ~0.1mM. The chemistry of citrate is complex with a variety of different binding modes reported. Binding of metal ions can occur at four sites: namely through the three carboxylate groups (pKa1 =3.13, pKa2 =4.76, pKa3 =6.40) and the hydroxy group (pK 4 ~11) , although the stability constants are sensitive to the medium . Furthermore, the deprotonation of the hydroxyl group of citric acid has proved a challenge for the determination of stability constants for metal citrates, and most studies treat citrate as the tribasic ligand H3L . A more recent determination of the deprotonation at neutral pH values provides a value of 14.4 for the fourth pKa , accounting for the hydroxyl deprotonation and making possible the assignment of the ligand as H4L in the affinity constant calculations. As shown in  , the structural chemistry of the metal citrates is quite complex with bidentate complexes binding through dicarboxy donors reported for Ni2+ , Ca2+ , and Ga3+ , bidentate complexes involving the hydroxy group described for Ti(IV) , and Al(III) , for example, and tridentate complexes reported for Cu2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Fe3+, and Cr3+, the latter showing different deprotonation states for the citrate ligands . The variety of dinuclear and oligomeric structures is consistent with the bridging propensity of the ligand donor groups . The majority of such complexes are mono-anionic with an important exception being the di-anionic Fe3+-citrate complex.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">While recent mass spectrometric studies of iron–citrate speciation demonstrate a complicated chemistry, one biologically relevant species has been identified as mononuclear dicitrate complex [Fe(L)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5−</ce:sup>, that is, a complex with fully deprotonated form of the ligand (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>) . While considerable effort has focused on the fundamental chemistry of the iron–citrate system , the chemistry of other metal cations of significance (those where uptake of the complex has been noted, even weakly compared to background citrate uptake ) such as Ba<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Sr<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Pb<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> is even less well developed. While the speciation and structural chemistry of the cadmium–citrate system has been investigated , the corresponding lead chemistry has not been systematically explored. The lead–citrate structural chemistry includes a two-dimensional material  and a three-dimensional material . Even less is known of Sr(II), with only a single polymeric structure reported to date for strontium . Such structures may simply reflect the requirements of the crystalline state and may not reflect the biologically relevant complexes. It would seem that the solution speciation of these cations with citrate, and analogs such as isocitrate and fluorocitrate, has not been adequately established .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: While recent mass spectrometric studies of iron-citrate speciation demonstrate a complicated chemistry, one biologically relevant species has been identified as mononuclear dicitrate complex [Fe(L)2]5-, that is, a complex with fully deprotonated form of the ligand ( ) . While considerable effort has focused on the fundamental chemistry of the iron-citrate system , the chemistry of other metal cations of significance (those where uptake of the complex has been noted, even weakly compared to background citrate uptake ) such as Ba2+, Sr2+ and Pb2+ is even less well developed. While the speciation and structural chemistry of the cadmium-citrate system has been investigated , the corresponding lead chemistry has not been systematically explored. The lead-citrate structural chemistry includes a two-dimensional material  and a three-dimensional material . Even less is known of Sr(II), with only a single polymeric structure reported to date for strontium . Such structures may simply reflect the requirements of the crystalline state and may not reflect the biologically relevant complexes. It would seem that the solution speciation of these cations with citrate, and analogs such as isocitrate and fluorocitrate, has not been adequately established .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">In view of our incomplete knowledge of the structural chemistries of heavy metal contaminants with citrate, we have undertaken a study of the solid state and solution chemistries of strontium, lead and cadmium with citrate under both physiological and non-physiological conditions. In this manuscript, we describe the synthesis and structure of a two-dimensional Pb(II)–citrate complex, {Na(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}[Pb<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·9.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) that was isolated as part of our on-going work.</ce:para>

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General considerations

All chemicals were used as obtained without further purification: lead(II) nitrate and trisodium citrate were purchased from Aldrich. The reactants were stirred briefly, and the initial pH measured before heating. Water was distilled above 3.0MΩ in-house using a Barnstead Model 525 Biopure Distilled Water Center. The initial and final pH of the reactions were measured using Hydrion pH sticks.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of {Na(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}[Pb<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·9.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Lead nitrate (0.0469<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.172<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and trisodium citrate (1.00<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 3.88<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were dissolved in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. After adjusting the pH to 4.5 with dilute HCl (2.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M), the solution was allowed to stand for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>weeks, whereupon clear crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained in 20% yield based on lead. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3403(s, br), 1561(s), 1387(s), 1270(m), 1136(m), 1075(m), 834(m), 623(m), 563(w). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">52</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">43.5</ce:inf>NaPb<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>: C, 13.8; H, 2.50. Found: C, 13.6; H, 2.43%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {Na(H2O)3}[Pb5(C6H5O7)3(C6H6O7)(H2O)3]⋅9.5H2O (1)

Lead nitrate (0.0469g, 0.172mmol) and trisodium citrate (1.00g, 3.88mmol) were dissolved in 10mL of H2O. After adjusting the pH to 4.5 with dilute HCl (2.0M), the solution was allowed to stand for 2weeks, whereupon clear crystals of 1 were obtained in 20% yield based on lead. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3403(s, br), 1561(s), 1387(s), 1270(m), 1136(m), 1075(m), 834(m), 623(m), 563(w). Anal. Calc. for C24H52O43.5NaPb5: C, 13.8; H, 2.50. Found: C, 13.6; H, 2.43%.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Crystallographic data for the compound was collected with a Bruker P4 diffractometer equipped with a SMART CCD system  and using MoKα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The data were collected at 90K and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects . Absorption corrections were made using sadabs . The structure solution and refinement were carried out using the shelxtl  crystallographic software package. The structures were solved using direct methods, and all of the nonhydrogen atoms were located from the initial solution. After locating all of the nonhydrogen atoms in each structure, except for the water molecules of crystallization, the model was refined against F 2, initially using isotropic, then anisotropic thermal displacement parameters, until the final value of Δ/σ max was less than 0.001. At this point in the refinement, there were several residual peaks within the interlamellar void from the Fourier difference map. However, the highly disordered solvent molecules within the void could not be adequately defined crystallographically. The SQUEEZE routine of the program platon  was used to subtract the contribution of the solvent of crystallization to the diffraction pattern. The SQUEEZE routine indicated that a total potential solvent area of 380Å3 [16.8% of the cell volume], and a void electron population of 191 per cell. Refinement after the SQUEEZE routine gave significantly improved R values: R values before SQUEEZE, R 1 =0.0865, wR 2 =0.2162. Crystal data for the compound is summarized in  . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1 are collected in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and infrared spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The title compound {Na(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}[Pb<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·9.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), was prepared in the reaction of the nitrate salt of Pb(II) with trisodium citrate Na<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> at pH 4.8. The optimal Pb:citrate ratio was found to be ca. 1:22.5. Other metal/ligand ratios (1:1–1:10) also yielded compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> but in lower yields and as microcrystalline materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and infrared spectroscopy

The title compound {Na(H2O)3}[Pb5(C6H5O7)3(C6H6O7)(H2O)3]⋅9.5H2O (1), was prepared in the reaction of the nitrate salt of Pb(II) with trisodium citrate Na3C6H7O7 at pH 4.8. The optimal Pb:citrate ratio was found to be ca. 1:22.5. Other metal/ligand ratios (1:1-1:10) also yielded compound 1 but in lower yields and as microcrystalline materials.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">The preparation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> requires the presence of sodium cations which provide charge compensation and occupy the interlamellar domain. In the absence of sodium, the previously reported [Pb(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)]·<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was isolated under the conditions of synthesis. Attempts to replace sodium with potassium, rubidium, cesium or alkylammonium cations produced amorphous mixtures. Although compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was prepared in aqueous media, it is insoluble in water at pH values less than 8.5. The compound dissolves upon slow addition of base and heating. When alcohol is added to the basic solution, an amorphous mixture is obtained.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The preparation of 1 requires the presence of sodium cations which provide charge compensation and occupy the interlamellar domain. In the absence of sodium, the previously reported [Pb(C6H6O7)]⋅nH2O was isolated under the conditions of synthesis. Attempts to replace sodium with potassium, rubidium, cesium or alkylammonium cations produced amorphous mixtures. Although compound 1 was prepared in aqueous media, it is insoluble in water at pH values less than 8.5. The compound dissolves upon slow addition of base and heating. When alcohol is added to the basic solution, an amorphous mixture is obtained.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) profiles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>·9.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O exhibit a weight loss of ca. 8% from room temperature to 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the loss of water of crystallization (8.2% calc.) (). This is followed by a plateau of stability between 100 and 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, whereupon there is a loss of ca. 34% by weight between 215 and 500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, attributed to the decomposition of the citrate ligands and loss of coordinated water (ca. 36.5% calc.). The product of the thermal decomposition is a gray amorphous material, presumably a mixture of sodium and lead oxides.</ce:para>

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>, there are four distinct citrate environments, three are triply-deprotonated and one is doubly deprotonated. In no instance is the hydroxyl group deprotonated, even in the solid state. This observation has significant biological implications since it has been postulated that lead-citrate structures are not metabolized because the hydroxyl group is necessary for aconitase recognition to turn the citric acid cycle (vide infra) . As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>, the previously reported lead citrate structures [Pb(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)]·<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  and [Pb<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  also exhibit protonated hydroxyl groups. However, the coordination modes adopted by the citrate are distinct in all seven cases and link from three to seven lead sites. In the case of the two-dimensional [Pb(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)]·<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, the citrate exhibits a protonated carboxyl group that projects into the interlamellar domain, in a fashion similar to that observed for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The three-dimensional [Pb<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] presents two distinct citrate environments, both bridging five Pb sites. In one mode, the citrate acts as a tridentate chelate to a single Pb site. In all three citrate environments of , the hydroxyl group participates in chelation to a Pb center, specifically by formation of five-membered {Pb–O–C–C–O–} chelate rings.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in  , there are four distinct citrate environments, three are triply-deprotonated and one is doubly deprotonated. In no instance is the hydroxyl group deprotonated, even in the solid state. This observation has significant biological implications since it has been postulated that lead-citrate structures are not metabolized because the hydroxyl group is necessary for aconitase recognition to turn the citric acid cycle (vide infra) . As shown in   , the previously reported lead citrate structures [Pb(C6H6O7)]⋅nH2O  and [Pb6(H2O)2(C6H5O7)4]⋅3H2O  also exhibit protonated hydroxyl groups. However, the coordination modes adopted by the citrate are distinct in all seven cases and link from three to seven lead sites. In the case of the two-dimensional [Pb(C6H6O7)]⋅nH2O, the citrate exhibits a protonated carboxyl group that projects into the interlamellar domain, in a fashion similar to that observed for 1. The three-dimensional [Pb6(H2O)2(C6H5O7)4] presents two distinct citrate environments, both bridging five Pb sites. In one mode, the citrate acts as a tridentate chelate to a single Pb site. In all three citrate environments of , the hydroxyl group participates in chelation to a Pb center, specifically by formation of five-membered {Pb-O-C-C-O-} chelate rings.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The four crystallographically and chemically distinct citrate groups of 1 link three, five, seven and seven lead sites, as shown in . In three instances, the citrate ligand adopts a tridentate chelating mode to a single lead center. In all three instances, as well as the tridentate chelation mode of [Pb<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>], the hydroxyl group participates in the tridentate chelate geometry. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> also provides the single instance of an uncoordinated –OH group, in the same citrate ligand that projects a –CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H group into the interlamellar domain.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The four crystallographically and chemically distinct citrate groups of 1 link three, five, seven and seven lead sites, as shown in . In three instances, the citrate ligand adopts a tridentate chelating mode to a single lead center. In all three instances, as well as the tridentate chelation mode of [Pb6(H2O)2(C6H5O7)4], the hydroxyl group participates in the tridentate chelate geometry. Compound 1 also provides the single instance of an uncoordinated -OH group, in the same citrate ligand that projects a -CO2H group into the interlamellar domain.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Hydroxyl coordination appears to play a significant role in the biology of metal citrate uptake. Two binding motifs are relevant for citrate binding to divalent cations: bidentate and tridentate . Bidentate complexes that bind through a dicarboxy motif have been reported for Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Ca<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>. Bidentate complexes involving the hydroxy group have been reported for Ti<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, and tridentate complexes for Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, and Pb<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>. Studies on the ability of <ce:italic>Pseudomonas fluorescens</ce:italic> to metabolize metal–citrate complexes shows that tridentate complexes are not metabolized, while bidentate Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Ca<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> complexes were metabolized . The implication is that the hydroxyl group needs to be uncoordinated so that aconitase can recognize the citrate. The observation of both bidentate and tridentate coordination modes of citrate for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may have implications for lead citrate bonding in solution and for metabolism of such compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Hydroxyl coordination appears to play a significant role in the biology of metal citrate uptake. Two binding motifs are relevant for citrate binding to divalent cations: bidentate and tridentate . Bidentate complexes that bind through a dicarboxy motif have been reported for Ni2+ and Ca2+. Bidentate complexes involving the hydroxy group have been reported for Ti2+, and tridentate complexes for Cu2+, Fe2+, Cd2+, and Pb2+. Studies on the ability of Pseudomonas fluorescens to metabolize metal-citrate complexes shows that tridentate complexes are not metabolized, while bidentate Ni2+ and Ca2+ complexes were metabolized . The implication is that the hydroxyl group needs to be uncoordinated so that aconitase can recognize the citrate. The observation of both bidentate and tridentate coordination modes of citrate for compound 1 may have implications for lead citrate bonding in solution and for metabolism of such compounds.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0090" view="all">Lead(II) compounds adopt a broad range of coordination numbers from 2 to 12 when counting nearest neighbors . The large variety of configurations of Pb(II) complexes reflects the stereochemical activity of the lone pair of electrons, now described as a result of an antibonding lead 6s-ligand np interaction that results in structural distortions to minimize the unfavorable interactions . Lead(II) complexes then fall into one of two categories: hemidirected where the electron distribution around the metal ion creates apparent gaps in the coordination sphere and homodirected where the electronic distribution and consequently the coordination sphere are symmetric .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Lead(II) compounds adopt a broad range of coordination numbers from 2 to 12 when counting nearest neighbors . The large variety of configurations of Pb(II) complexes reflects the stereochemical activity of the lone pair of electrons, now described as a result of an antibonding lead 6s-ligand np interaction that results in structural distortions to minimize the unfavorable interactions . Lead(II) complexes then fall into one of two categories: hemidirected where the electron distribution around the metal ion creates apparent gaps in the coordination sphere and homodirected where the electronic distribution and consequently the coordination sphere are symmetric .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0115" view="all">The reaction of lead(II) nitrate with trisodium citrate provides the polymeric solid {Na(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}[Pb<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·9.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). The complex two-dimensional structure consists of interconnected chains of {PbO<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>} polyhedra and citrate units. The sodium cation which provides charge compensation and bonds to the pendant –CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H group of the (C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> group, is essential for the crystallization of the layer structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The reaction of lead(II) nitrate with trisodium citrate provides the polymeric solid {Na(H2O)3}[Pb5(C6H5O7)3(C6H6O7)(H2O)3]⋅9.5H2O (1). The complex two-dimensional structure consists of interconnected chains of {PbO n } polyhedra and citrate units. The sodium cation which provides charge compensation and bonds to the pendant -CO2H group of the (C6H6O7)2- group, is essential for the crystallization of the layer structure.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0120" view="all">The structure exhibits four distinct citrate environments. In three cases, the ligand adopts a tridentate chelating coordination mode. This chelating mode is significant in view of the observation that hydroxyl coordination plays a role in the biology of metal citrate uptake. Specifically, it appears that complexes with tridentate coordination are not metabolized and that the hydroxyl groups must be uncoordinated to effect recognition. It is noteworthy that of seven citrate coordination modes observed to date for lead citrates, six implicate hydroxyl bonding. The only instance of a free hydroxyl group involves sodium coordination to a –CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H group of the citrate of the uncoordinated hydroxyl group. The role of other cations in metal citrate bonding has not been investigated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structure exhibits four distinct citrate environments. In three cases, the ligand adopts a tridentate chelating coordination mode. This chelating mode is significant in view of the observation that hydroxyl coordination plays a role in the biology of metal citrate uptake. Specifically, it appears that complexes with tridentate coordination are not metabolized and that the hydroxyl groups must be uncoordinated to effect recognition. It is noteworthy that of seven citrate coordination modes observed to date for lead citrates, six implicate hydroxyl bonding. The only instance of a free hydroxyl group involves sodium coordination to a -CO2H group of the citrate of the uncoordinated hydroxyl group. The role of other cations in metal citrate bonding has not been investigated.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0125" view="all">The lead sites of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibit exclusively the hemidirected coordination type where there is as unevenly distributed coordination sphere with an obvious gap as a consequence of the stereochemically active lone pair. The coordination numbers for the lead sites of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be classified as ‘5+3’, ‘5+4’, ‘6+4’, and ‘7+3’ in terms of proximal ligands and distal neighbors.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The lead sites of 1 exhibit exclusively the hemidirected coordination type where there is as unevenly distributed coordination sphere with an obvious gap as a consequence of the stereochemically active lone pair. The coordination numbers for the lead sites of 1 may be classified as ‘5+3', ‘5+4', ‘6+4', and ‘7+3' in terms of proximal ligands and distal neighbors.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0130" view="all">While the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> provides some information on lead–citrate bonding modes, the question of lead citrate speciation in solution remains to be addressed. At physiological pH, citrate would be expected to be present in the deprotonated, trianionic form (C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, which would be consistent with studies that suggest mononuclear species of the type {Pb(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)}<ce:sup loc="post">1−</ce:sup> to dominate . In order to establish the identities of the lead–citrate species in solution, we have begun extensive electroscopy ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) studies on lead citrate solutions of various stoichiometries and over a range of pH values .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: While the structure of 1 provides some information on lead-citrate bonding modes, the question of lead citrate speciation in solution remains to be addressed. At physiological pH, citrate would be expected to be present in the deprotonated, trianionic form (C6H5O7)3-, which would be consistent with studies that suggest mononuclear species of the type {Pb(C6H5O7)}1- to dominate . In order to establish the identities of the lead-citrate species in solution, we have begun extensive electroscopy ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) studies on lead citrate solutions of various stoichiometries and over a range of pH values .

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {Na(H2O)3}[Pb5(C6H5O7)3(C6H6O7)(H2O)3]⋅9.5H2O (1)

Lead nitrate (0.0469g, 0.172mmol) and trisodium citrate (1.00g, 3.88mmol) were dissolved in 10mL of H2O. After adjusting the pH to 4.5 with dilute HCl (2.0M), the solution was allowed to stand for 2weeks, whereupon clear crystals of 1 were obtained in 20% yield based on lead. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3403(s, br), 1561(s), 1387(s), 1270(m), 1136(m), 1075(m), 834(m), 623(m), 563(w). Anal. Calc. for C24H52O43.5NaPb5: C, 13.8; H, 2.50. Found: C, 13.6; H, 2.43%.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The reaction of lead(II) nitrate with trisodium citrate Na3(C6H5O7) in a 1:22.5 ratio at pH 4.8 provides crystals of {Na(H2O)3}[Pb5(H2O)3(C6H5O7)3(C6H6O7)]⋅9.5H2O (1). The structure of 1 is two-dimensional and exhibits five distinct Pb(II) sites and four different modes of citrate bonding. The five lead sites all display hemidirected coordination geometries, that is, irregular distribution of neighboring oxygen atoms resulting in obvious gaps in the coordination spheres. Consequently, the lead coordination geometries exhibit proximal bonding to a number of oxygen donors, as well as distal interactions with nearest neighbors. The coordination numbers vary from 8 to 10, with ‘5+3', ‘5+4', ‘6+4' and ‘7+3' coordination modes where the first number refers to the proximal ligands and the second to the distal set. The four crystallographically distinct citrate groups include three with deprotonated carboxylate groups (C6H5O7)3- and one with a single protonated carboxyl group (C6H6O7)2. The citrate ligands bridge 3, 5, 7 and 7 lead sites. Three of the citrate groups exhibit tridentate chelation coordination to a lead site through two carboxylate oxygen donors and the hydroxyl groups. One citrate group projects an uncoordinated -OH group and a pendant protonated carboxyl group into the interlamellar domain. This latter carboxyl group coordinates to a sodium cation, which exhibits five coordinate geometry defined by three aqua ligands and the carbonyl oxygen of the -CO2H groups in the basal plane and a citrate -OH donor in the apical position.

X-ray crystallography

Crystallographic data for the compound was collected with a Bruker P4 diffractometer equipped with a SMART CCD system  and using MoKα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The data were collected at 90K and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects . Absorption corrections were made using sadabs . The structure solution and refinement were carried out using the shelxtl  crystallographic software package. The structures were solved using direct methods, and all of the nonhydrogen atoms were located from the initial solution. After locating all of the nonhydrogen atoms in each structure, except for the water molecules of crystallization, the model was refined against F 2, initially using isotropic, then anisotropic thermal displacement parameters, until the final value of Δ/σ max was less than 0.001. At this point in the refinement, there were several residual peaks within the interlamellar void from the Fourier difference map. However, the highly disordered solvent molecules within the void could not be adequately defined crystallographically. The SQUEEZE routine of the program platon  was used to subtract the contribution of the solvent of crystallization to the diffraction pattern. The SQUEEZE routine indicated that a total potential solvent area of 380Å3 [16.8% of the cell volume], and a void electron population of 191 per cell. Refinement after the SQUEEZE routine gave significantly improved R values: R values before SQUEEZE, R 1 =0.0865, wR 2 =0.2162. Crystal data for the compound is summarized in  . Selected bond lengths and angles for 1 are collected in  .

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) profiles of 1⋅9.5H2O exhibit a weight loss of ca. 8% from room temperature to 100°C, corresponding to the loss of water of crystallization (8.2% calc.) (). This is followed by a plateau of stability between 100 and 200°C, whereupon there is a loss of ca. 34% by weight between 215 and 500°C, attributed to the decomposition of the citrate ligands and loss of coordinated water (ca. 36.5% calc.). The product of the thermal decomposition is a gray amorphous material, presumably a mixture of sodium and lead oxides.

decomposition temperature.type: decomposition of the citrate ligands and loss of coordinated water

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp020" view="all">(a) A ball and stick representation of the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in the <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane, showing two neighboring layers; hydrogen atoms, sodium cations and water molecules of crystallization have been omitted for clarity. (b) A mixed polyhedral and ball and stick view of the layer structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, showing the locations of the sodium cations and the coordinated water molecules. Color scheme: lead, dark gray spheres (a) or polyhedra (b); sodium, yellow spheres; oxygen, red spheres; carbon, black spheres. (For interpretation of the references in colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>
